Indications and doses

Prevention and treatment of ventricular and supraventricular arrhythmias, including after myocardial infarction, Maintenance of sinus rhythm after cardioversion,

Initially by slow intravenous injection

  • For adults
    300–800 mg daily in divided doses.
  • For adults
    250–375 mg every 12 hours.
  • For adults
    Loading dose 2 mg/kg (max. per dose 150 mg), dose to be given over at least 5 minutes with ECG monitoring, followed immediately by (by mouth using immediate-release medicines) initially 200 mg, then (by mouth using immediate-release medicines) 200 mg every 8 hours for 24 hours, alternatively (by intravenous infusion) 400 micrograms/kg/hour, maximum 300 mg given in the first hour; maximum 800 mg per day.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises use only if potential benefit outweighs risk; may induce labour if used in third trimester.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Half-life prolonged—may need dose reduction.

Avoid modified-release preparation.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Reduce dose by increasing dose interval; adjust according to response.

Avoid modified-release preparation.

Contra indications

  • Bundle-branch block associated with first-degree AV block
  • second- and third-degree AV block or bifascicular block (unless pacemaker fitted)
  • severe heart failure (unless secondary to arrhythmia)
  • severe sinus node dysfunction

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Angle-closure glaucoma, antimuscarinic effects, AV block, blurred vision, cholestatic jaundice, dry mouth, gastro-intestinal irritation, hypoglycaemia, hypotension, myocardial depression, psychosis, urinary retention, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation or torsade de pointes (usually associated with prolongation of QRS complex or QT interval),

Directions for administration

With intravenous use

For intravenous infusion (Rythmodan ), given continuously or intermittently in Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%. Max. rate by continuous infusion 20–30 mg/hour (or 400 micrograms/kg/hour).

Cautions regarding administration

  • Atrial flutter or atrial tachycardia with partial block
  • avoid in Acute porphyrias
  • elderly
  • heart failure (avoid if severe)
  • myasthenia gravis
  • prostatic enlargement
  • structural heart disease
  • susceptibility to angle-closure glaucoma

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor for hypotension, hypoglycaemia, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation or torsade de pointes (discontinue if occur).

Monitor serum potassium.

Prepared medicinal forms of DISOPYRAMIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral solution, oral suspension,
Modified-release tablet
Capsule
